DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to see whether giving acetaminophen (the medicine in Tylenol) for routine infant vaccinations is helpful in preventing fever or other symptoms.
DOC.brief_title: Acetaminophen Before Vaccines for Infants Study (AVIS)
DOC.detailed_description: Post-vaccination fever occurs in up to 40% of infants receiving routinely recommended childhood vaccinations. Although serious events are rare, post-vaccination fever causes discomfort for the child, can lead to medical utilization, can rarely result in febrile seizure, and can cause a working parent to miss time from their job to care for a febrile infant who cannot attend day care. The benefits of acetaminophen prophylaxis for infants receiving current vaccinations, in terms of reduction of discomfort for the child, improvement of quality-of-life indicators for the parent, or reduction of medical utilization, have not been measured. This randomized, blinded, placebo-controlled trial will assess the efficacy of prophylaxis with acetaminophen in prevention of fever following routine childhood immunizations.
DOC.criteria: 1. Child is a current Group Health enrollee. 2. Child will be seen at a Group Health clinic for a Well Child visit that is expected to include 2 or more vaccines after 6 wks and before 10 months of age. 1. If child was born at less than 36 weeks of gestation, the child is not eligible until 4 months of age or older. 2. If the child's birth weight was less than 5.5 pounds (2500 grams), the child is not eligible until 4 months of age or older.
